elements.content: Six new coordination polymers, namely, [Zn(3-PyHBIm)(oba)H2O] (1), [Cd(3-PyHBIm)(oba)H2O] (2), [Ni(3-PyHBIm)(oba)H2O]·3H2O (3), [Zn(4-PyHBIm)(oba)] (4), [Cd(4-PyHBIm)2(oba)]·H2O(5), and [Co(4-PyHBIm)2(oba)]·H2O (6) were synthesized under hydrothermal conditions based on 2-(n-pyridyl)benzimidazole (n-PyHBIm) and 4,4′-oxybis-(benzoate) (oba) ligands. The compounds were characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction, IR, and thermogravimetric and elemental analyses. Compounds 1 and 2 contain simple one-dimensional (1D) polymeric chains assembled into a three-dimensional (3D) network through aromatic π–π stacking interactions and hydrogen bonding interactions. Compound 3 contains 1D polymeric chains with side arms which assembled into a two-dimensional (2D) network with channels and further assembled into a 3D network though C–H···π interactions. Compounds 4 and 5 form 1D molecular ladder coordination polymers. Compound 6 consists of 2D coordination networks with 2-fold interpenetration. The luminescence properties of 1, 2, 4, and 5 were studied in the solid state at room temperature.

The compounds were characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction, IR, and thermogravimetric and elemental analyses. Compounds 4 and 5 form 1D molecular ladder coordination polymers. Compound 6 consists of 2D coordination networks with 2-fold interpenetration. The luminescence properties of 1, 2, 4, and 5 were studied in the solid state at room temperature.

elements.content: Metal–organic coordination polymers have attracted great interest not only because of their intriguing structural motifs but also for the potential applications in the field of functional materials such as catalysis, luminescence, molecular based magnet, ion exchange, and adsorption. Crystal engineering based on coordination polymer is an efficient strategy for designing and synthesizing metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) with elegant topologies and potential applications. Much effort has been done on the rational design and controlled synthesis of coordination polymers, but it is still a great challenge to predict the structures and properties of metal–organic coordination polymers. The final structures of metal–organic coordination polymers are dependent upon multiple factors, among which the most important ones are the geometrical and electronic properties of the metal ions and ligands. The structural geometry can be controlled and modulated by selecting the coordination geometry of metal ions and the chemical nature of the terminal and bridging ligands. The common process to control the structures of the coordination polymers is using N-heterocyclic ligands and polycarboxylate. 2-(n-Pyridyl)benzimidazole ligands have three N-donors, which can play many kinds of roles in coordination polymers. Especially, the conjugate aromatic nucleus will contribute to form interesting structures though aromatic π–π stacking interactions. 4,4′-Oxybis-(benzoate) (oba) is a flexible carboxylate ligand, which has been investigated a lot and proved to be a very good bridging ligand. We herein report a series of coordination polymers based on n-PyHBIm (n = 3, 4) and oba ligands. Compounds 1 and 2 contain simple one-dimensional (1D) polymeric chains assembled into a three-dimensional (3D) network through aromatic π–π stacking interactions and hydrogen bonding interactions. Compound 3 contains 1D polymeric chains with side arms which assembled into a two-dimensional (2D) network with channels and further assembled into a 3D network though C–H···π interactions. Compounds 4 and 5 form 1D molecular ladder coordination polymers. Compound 6 consists of 2D coordination networks with 2-fold interpenetration. The thermal stabilities of 1–6 and photoluminescence properties of 1, 2, 4, and 5 have also been investigated.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic coordination polymers have attracted great interest not only because of their intriguing structural motifs but also for the potential applications in the field of functional materials such as catalysis, luminescence, molecular based magnet, ion exchange, and adsorption. Crystal engineering based on coordination polymer is an efficient strategy for designing and synthesizing metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with elegant topologies and potential applications. Much effort has been done on the rational design and controlled synthesis of coordination polymers, but it is still a great challenge to predict the structures and properties of metal-organic coordination polymers. The final structures of metal-organic coordination polymers are dependent upon multiple factors, among which the most important ones are the geometrical and electronic properties of the metal ions and ligands. The structural geometry can be controlled and modulated by selecting the coordination geometry of metal ions and the chemical nature of the terminal and bridging ligands. The common process to control the structures of the coordination polymers is using N-heterocyclic ligands and polycarboxylate. 2-(n-Pyridyl)benzimidazole ligands have three N-donors, which can play many kinds of roles in coordination polymers. Especially, the conjugate aromatic nucleus will contribute to form interesting structures though aromatic π-π stacking interactions. 4,4'-Oxybis-(benzoate) (oba) is a flexible carboxylate ligand, which has been investigated a lot and proved to be a very good bridging ligand. We herein report a series of coordination polymers based on n-PyHBIm (n = 3, 4) and oba ligands. Compounds 1 and 2 contain simple one-dimensional (1D) polymeric chains assembled into a three-dimensional (3D) network through aromatic π-π stacking interactions and hydrogen bonding interactions. Compound 3 contains 1D polymeric chains with side arms which assembled into a two-dimensional (2D) network with channels and further assembled into a 3D network though C-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions. Compounds 4 and 5 form 1D molecular ladder coordination polymers. Compound 6 consists of 2D coordination networks with 2-fold interpenetration. The thermal stabilities of 1-6 and photoluminescence properties of 1, 2, 4, and 5 have also been investigated.

elements.content: The ligand 2-(n-pyridyl)benzimidazole (n = 3, 4) was synthesized in accordance with the procedure reported by Alcade et al. Other reagents and solvents employed were commercially available and used as received without further purification. Elemental analyses for carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen atoms were determined with a PE 2400 Elemental analyzer. The infrared spectra of KBr pellets were recorded with a BRUKER EQUINOX-55 spectrometer in the range of 4000–400 cm–1. Fluorescent spectra for the solid samples were recorded with a Hitachi F-4500 fluorescence spectrophotometer. Thermogravimetric analyses were performed on a NETZSCH STA 449C microanalyzer in a N2 atmosphere at a heating rate of 10 K/min between ambient temperature and 800 °C.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

The ligand 2-(n-pyridyl)benzimidazole (n = 3, 4) was synthesized in accordance with the procedure reported by Alcade et al. Other reagents and solvents employed were commercially available and used as received without further purification. Elemental analyses for carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen atoms were determined with a PE 2400 Elemental analyzer. The infrared spectra of KBr pellets were recorded with a BRUKER EQUINOX-55 spectrometer in the range of 4000-400 cm-1. Fluorescent spectra for the solid samples were recorded with a Hitachi F-4500 fluorescence spectrophotometer. Thermogravimetric analyses were performed on a NETZSCH STA 449C microanalyzer in a N2 atmosphere at a heating rate of 10 K/min between ambient temperature and 800 °C.

elements.content: A solution of Zn(OAc)2·2H2O (23.0 mg, 0.105 mmol), 3-PyHBIm (19.6 mg, 0.1 mmol), oba acid (25.8 mg, 0.1 mmol), NaOH (4.0 mg, 0.1 mmol), and H2O (15 mL) was stirred under ambient conditions, then sealed in a Teflon-lined steel autoclave, heated at 160 °C for 5 days, and cooled to room temperature. The resulting product was recovered by filtration, washed with distilled water, and dried in air (60% yield). Anal. Calcd for C26H21N3O7Zn: C, 56.49; H, 3.83; N, 7.60. Found: C, 56.27; H, 3.62; N, 7.29. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3074.6m, 1593.2s, 1534.0s, 1500.2m, 1414.9s, 1235.5s, 1161.4m, 968.5w, 877.8m, 783.3m, 764.7m, 696.0m, 660.8m, 431.7w.

elements.content: Suitable single crystals of 1–6 were carefully selected under an optical microscope and glued to thin glass fibers. The diffraction data were collected on a Siemens SMART CCD diffractometer with graphite monochromated MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 298 K. An empirical absorption correction was applied using the SADABS program. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on F 2 by using the SHELX-97 program package. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms of PyHBIm were generated geometrically, and no attempts were made to locate the hydrogen atoms of water. The crystallography details for the structures determination of 1–6 are presented in Table . Selected bond distances and bond angles are listed in Table .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Suitable single crystals of 1-6 were carefully selected under an optical microscope and glued to thin glass fibers. The diffraction data were collected on a Siemens SMART CCD diffractometer with graphite monochromated MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 298 K. An empirical absorption correction was applied using the SADABS program. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on F 2 by using the SHELX-97 program package. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms of PyHBIm were generated geometrically, and no attempts were made to locate the hydrogen atoms of water. The crystallography details for the structures determination of 1-6 are presented in Table . Selected bond distances and bond angles are listed in Table .

elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structures

Compounds 1 and 2 

Single-crystal X-ray analyses revealed that compounds 1 and 2 are isomorphous, so that only the structure of 1 is described here. There is one Zn(II) atom in the asymmetric unit of 1 with distorted octahedral coordination geometry. The Zn1 ion is coordinated by four oxygen atoms (O2, O3, O5, and O6) from oba ligand, one nitrogen atom (N1) from 3-PyHBIm ligand, and one oxygen atom (O1) from water. The Zn-O bond distances are in the range of 2.028(3)-2.347(3) Å, while the Zn-N bond length is 2.112(3) Å, and the selected bond angles are listed in Table .

elements.content: The neighboring Zn atoms are bridged by oba ligand and form a 1D linear chain structure (Figure a). 3-PyHBIm sticks out from the 1D chain and forms π–π stacking interactions with one benzene ring of oba ligand from adjacent chain, which leads the 1D chain structure into a 2D layer network (Figure b). Such 2D layers are further extended into the the 3D supramolecular network via hydrogen bonding interactions. The coordinated water and the free water molecules form multiple hydrogen bonds with nitrogen atoms (N2 and N3) from 3-PyHBIm ligand and oxygen atoms (O3 and O5) from oba ligand ().

Such 2D layers are further extended into the the 3D supramolecular network via hydrogen bonding interactions. The coordinated water and the free water molecules form multiple hydrogen bonds with nitrogen atoms (N2 and N3) from 3-PyHBIm ligand and oxygen atoms (O3 and O5) from oba ligand ().

elements.content: X-ray crystallographic data showed that compound 3 crystallizes in triclinic space group P1̅. As depicted in Figure a, there is one Ni(II) atom in the asymmetric unit of 3 with distorted octahedral coordination geometry. The Ni1 is surrounded by two nitrogen atoms (N1 and N4) from two different 3-PyHBIm ligands, three oxygen atoms (O2, O3, and O5) from two individual oba ligands and one oxygen atom (O1) from water. The Ni–O bond distances are in the range of 2.027(3)–2.128(3) Å, and the O–Ni–O bond angles vary from 93.71(13) to 164.00(12)°, while the Ni–N bond lengths are 2.080(4) and 2.089(4) Å, respectively, and the N–Ni–N bond angle is 175.61(13)°(Table ).
elements.clean_text:
Compound 3 

X-ray crystallographic data showed that compound 3 crystallizes in triclinic space group P1̅. As depicted in Figure a, there is one Ni(II) atom in the asymmetric unit of 3 with distorted octahedral coordination geometry. The Ni1 is surrounded by two nitrogen atoms (N1 and N4) from two different 3-PyHBIm ligands, three oxygen atoms (O2, O3, and O5) from two individual oba ligands and one oxygen atom (O1) from water. The Ni-O bond distances are in the range of 2.027(3)-2.128(3) Å, and the O-Ni-O bond angles vary from 93.71(13) to 164.00(12)°, while the Ni-N bond lengths are 2.080(4) and 2.089(4) Å, respectively, and the N-Ni-N bond angle is 175.61(13)°(Table ).

elements.content: (a) Coordination environment of Ni(II)) in 3. (b) The 2D network formed though π–π interactions. (c) The simplified 2D network model of compound 3. (d) The 3D structure of 3 formed by C–H···π interactions.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Coordination environment of Ni(II)) in 3. (b) The 2D network formed though π-π interactions. (c) The simplified 2D network model of compound 3. (d) The 3D structure of 3 formed by C-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions.

elements.content: The extended structure shows that each NiII is further connected to form a 1D chain coordination polymer with two side arms. Two 3-PyHBIm ligands decorate from two sides of the 1D chainlike arms which lead to the 2D layer network though aromatic π–π stacking interactions (Figure b). When the π–π interaction is considered independently, the structure of complex 3 displays a 2-fold interpenetrated 2D network (). Besides, there are channels filled with free water molecules in the 2D layer network. These 2D layer networks further assembled into a 3D network though C–H···π interactions between oba ligands (Figure d).

Besides, there are channels filled with free water molecules in the 2D layer network. These 2D layer networks further assembled into a 3D network though C-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions between oba ligands (Figure d).

elements.content: The crystal structure of 4 reveals that the ZnII is coordinated to two nitrogen atoms (N1 and N3) of two 4-PyHBIm molecules and three oxygen atoms (O1, O2 and O5) of two oba ligands. Figure a shows the coordination environment of ZnII with a distorted trigonal bipyramidal configuration in 4. The Ni–O bond distances are in the range of 1.958(3)–2.189(6) Å, and the O–Ni–O bond angles vary from 58.6(2) to 125.12(17)°, while the Ni–N bond lengths are 2.103(4) and 2.076(4) Å, respectively, and the N–Ni–N bond angle is 108.67(15)° (Table ).

Compound 4 

The crystal structure of 4 reveals that the ZnII is coordinated to two nitrogen atoms (N1 and N3) of two 4-PyHBIm molecules and three oxygen atoms (O1, O2 and O5) of two oba ligands. Figure a shows the coordination environment of ZnII with a distorted trigonal bipyramidal configuration in 4. The Ni-O bond distances are in the range of 1.958(3)-2.189(6) Å, and the O-Ni-O bond angles vary from 58.6(2) to 125.12(17)°, while the Ni-N bond lengths are 2.103(4) and 2.076(4) Å, respectively, and the N-Ni-N bond angle is 108.67(15)° (Table ).

elements.content: (a) Coordination environment of Zn(II) in 4. (b) The 1D ladder-like chain structure of 4. (c) The polyrotaxane-like motif though π–π interactions in compound 4. (d) The 2-fold interpenetrated 2D network formed by π–π interactions in 4.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Coordination environment of Zn(II) in 4. (b) The 1D ladder-like chain structure of 4. (c) The polyrotaxane-like motif though π-π interactions in compound 4. (d) The 2-fold interpenetrated 2D network formed by π-π interactions in 4.

elements.content: The extended structure shows that each ZnII is further connected to form a 1D ladder coordination polymer running along the [110] axis (Figure b), with cavity dimensions measured by Zn···Zn distance of approximately 14.42 × 7.27 Å. In this structure, the 4-PyHBIm ligand takes an end to end fashion and acts as bridge to connect two Zn(II) ions. And the two carboxyl groups of oba ligand take different coordination modes to bridge two ZnII ions.
elements.clean_text: The extended structure shows that each ZnII is further connected to form a 1D ladder coordination polymer running along the [110] axis (Figure b), with cavity dimensions measured by Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn distance of approximately 14.42 × 7.27 Å. In this structure, the 4-PyHBIm ligand takes an end to end fashion and acts as bridge to connect two Zn(II) ions. And the two carboxyl groups of oba ligand take different coordination modes to bridge two ZnII ions.

elements.content: There are two kinds of weak interactions between the ladder chains which make a great contribution to stabilizing the structure of complex 4. The first is hydrogen bonding interactions between the N atoms of 4-PyHBIm ligands from one ladder chain and the uncoordinated carboxylate oxygen atoms from the neighboring ladder chain (N···O 2.7 Å) (). The second is aromatic π–π interactions (face to face distance: 3.96 Å) between 4-PyHBIm ligands from interval 1D ladder chains inside the cavity showing a polyrotaxane-like motif (Figure c). Notably, when the π–π interaction is considered independently, the structure of complex 4 displays a 2-fold interpenetrated 2D network having polyrotaxane character (Figure d). This structure of complex 4 is similar to that reported by Chen in [Cu2(bpa)2(phen)2(H2O)]2·2H2O (bpa2– = biphenyl-4,4′-dicarboxylate, phen = 1,10-phenanthroline), which is assembled into a 2D polyrotanxane network via aromatic π–π interactions.

elements.content: X-ray crystallographic data showed that complex 5 crystallizes in triclinic space group P1̅. As depicted in Figure a, there is one Cd(II) atom in the asymmetric unit of 5 with distorted pentagonal bipyramid coordination geometry. The Cd1 is surrounded by two nitrogen atoms (N1 and N4) from two different 4-PyHBIm ligands and five oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O4, O5, and O2B) from three individual oba ligands. The Cd–O bond distances are in the range of 2.298(4)–2.630 (4) Å, and the O–Cd–O bond angles vary from 52.28(14) to 167.10(15)°, while the Cd–N bond lengths are 2.312(6) and 2.381(5) Å, respectively, and the N–Cd–N bond angle is 173.59(19)° (Table ).

elements.content: A 1D ladder-like Cd-oba chain is formed through the oba ligands and Cd(II) atoms (Figure ), in which there are Cd2N4(CO2)4 binuclear secondary building units (SBUs) with a Cd–Cd distance of 4.39 Å. This SBUs is similar to that reported by Su and others. Meanwhile, 4-PyHBIm ligands decorate from the opposite sides of the the 1D chain. Such 1D ladder-like chains are further extended into the final 3D supramolecular network via π–π stacking interactions of 4-PyHBIm rings and hydrogen bonding interactions from different chains.

elements.content: A 2D layer is formed through the oba ligands and Co(II) atoms with cavity dimensions measured by a Co···Co distance of approximately 14.42 Å × 12.27 Å, in which there are Co2N4(CO2)4 binuclear secondary building units (SBUs) with a Co–Co distance of 4.03 Å (Figure b). This SBUs is similar to that reported by Varughese and others. To fill the large cavity in a single layer, two layers sharing the common plane defined by metal ions are interpenetrated with each other in a parallel fashion to give a double-layer network (Figure c). Meanwhile, 4-PyHBIm ligands decorate from opposite sides of the 2D layer like wings. Such 2D layers are further extended into the final 3D supramolecular network via π–π stacking interactions of 4-PyHBIm rings and hydrogen bonding interactions from different layers.
elements.clean_text: A 2D layer is formed through the oba ligands and Co(II) atoms with cavity dimensions measured by a Co⋅⋅⋅Co distance of approximately 14.42 Å × 12.27 Å, in which there are Co2N4(CO2)4 binuclear secondary building units (SBUs) with a Co-Co distance of 4.03 Å (Figure b). This SBUs is similar to that reported by Varughese and others. To fill the large cavity in a single layer, two layers sharing the common plane defined by metal ions are interpenetrated with each other in a parallel fashion to give a double-layer network (Figure c). Meanwhile, 4-PyHBIm ligands decorate from opposite sides of the 2D layer like wings. Such 2D layers are further extended into the final 3D supramolecular network via π-π stacking interactions of 4-PyHBIm rings and hydrogen bonding interactions from different layers.

elements.content: Six coordination polymers with n-PyHBIm (n = 3,4) and oba have been synthesized and described. All these compounds, with different metal centers (Zn(II), Cd(II), Co(II), and Ni(II)), were synthesized under similar conditions, but they exhibit distinct coordination structures. In compounds 1–3, they show two different kinds of structures with the same ligand 3-PyHBIm and oba. In compounds 1 and 2, each metal center (Zn(II) and Cd(II)) connects one 3-PyHBIm ligand, and when the metal center is replaced by Ni(II), each Ni(II) connects two 3-PyHBIm ligands in compound 3. All the 3-PyHBIm ligands take the end-on fashion which leaves the conjugate aromatic nucleus free to form π–π stacking interactions, which leads to a 2D layer network in compounds 1 and 2 and a 2D network with 2-fold interpenetration in compound 3. For compounds 4–6, they exhibit three distinct structures with the same ligands 4-PyHBIm and oba. In compound 4, the 4-PyHBIm ligand takes the end-to-end fashion and acts as bridge to connect two Zn(II) ions, which leads to a 2-fold interpenetrated 2D network having polyrotaxane character though π–π stacking interactions. In compound 5, the metal center is replaced by Cd(II) and forms binuclear secondary building units, in which the 4-PyHBIm ligand takes the end-on fashion. Compound 5 forms a 1D ladder-like chain structure and further assembled into a 3D supramolecular network. In the case of 6, 4-PyHBIm ligand also takes the end-on fashion, while the metal center is replaced by Co(II) and forms a binuclear motif. Compound 6 forms a 2D double-layer network with 2-fold interpenetration and further extended into the final 3D supramolecular network through π–π stacking interactions. Comparing compounds 5 and 6, the binuclear SBUs dominant the final structures. When these two compounds are compared to compound 4, we can realize that the combination of 4-PyHBIm ligand plays an important role in forming these structures. When comparing compounds 1–3 to compounds 4–6, we can find out that the position of nitrogen atom in n-PyHBIm ligand plays a pivotal role in forming coordination polymers.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Discussion

Six coordination polymers with n-PyHBIm (n = 3,4) and oba have been synthesized and described. All these compounds, with different metal centers (Zn(II), Cd(II), Co(II), and Ni(II)), were synthesized under similar conditions, but they exhibit distinct coordination structures. In compounds 1-3, they show two different kinds of structures with the same ligand 3-PyHBIm and oba. In compounds 1 and 2, each metal center (Zn(II) and Cd(II)) connects one 3-PyHBIm ligand, and when the metal center is replaced by Ni(II), each Ni(II) connects two 3-PyHBIm ligands in compound 3. All the 3-PyHBIm ligands take the end-on fashion which leaves the conjugate aromatic nucleus free to form π-π stacking interactions, which leads to a 2D layer network in compounds 1 and 2 and a 2D network with 2-fold interpenetration in compound 3. For compounds 4-6, they exhibit three distinct structures with the same ligands 4-PyHBIm and oba. In compound 4, the 4-PyHBIm ligand takes the end-to-end fashion and acts as bridge to connect two Zn(II) ions, which leads to a 2-fold interpenetrated 2D network having polyrotaxane character though π-π stacking interactions. In compound 5, the metal center is replaced by Cd(II) and forms binuclear secondary building units, in which the 4-PyHBIm ligand takes the end-on fashion. Compound 5 forms a 1D ladder-like chain structure and further assembled into a 3D supramolecular network. In the case of 6, 4-PyHBIm ligand also takes the end-on fashion, while the metal center is replaced by Co(II) and forms a binuclear motif. Compound 6 forms a 2D double-layer network with 2-fold interpenetration and further extended into the final 3D supramolecular network through π-π stacking interactions. Comparing compounds 5 and 6, the binuclear SBUs dominant the final structures. When these two compounds are compared to compound 4, we can realize that the combination of 4-PyHBIm ligand plays an important role in forming these structures. When comparing compounds 1-3 to compounds 4-6, we can find out that the position of nitrogen atom in n-PyHBIm ligand plays a pivotal role in forming coordination polymers.

elements.content: Thermal stabilities of compounds 1–6. Themogravimetric analyses (TGA) for compounds 1–6 were performed in N2 atmosphere between 20 and 800 °C (). For compound 1, a weight loss of 6.9% was observed below 130 °C, which is attributed to the release of the coordinated and free water molecules (calcd. 6.5%), and then the decomposition of the framework occurred at about 350 °C. In the case of 2, there was a weight loss of 6.1% below 150 °C, which is attributed to the release of coordinated and free water molecules (calcd. 6.0%), and then the decomposition of the framework occurred at about 350 °C. Compound 3 showed a weight of 9.3% occurring in the range of 20–140 °C corresponding to the release of the coordinated and free water molecules (calcd. 9.3%), and then the framework started to decompose at about 200 °C. Compound 4 was stable up to near 390 °C and then began to decompose. For compound 5, there is a weight loss of 2.7% below 110 °C, which corresponds to the release of free water molecules (calcd. 2.3%), and then the decomposition of the framework occurred at about 380 °C. In the case of 6, there is a weight loss of 2.6% in the range of 20–150 °C corresponding to the release of the free water molecules (calcd. 2.5%), and then the decomposition of the framework occurred at about 300 °C.

elements.content: Coordination polymers with d10 metal centers have various fluorescence properties with potential applications in many fields such as chemical sensors, photochemistry, and light-emitting diodes (LEDs). The solid-state photoluminescent spectra of compounds 1, 2, 4, and 5 were measured at room temperature, and the results are given in Figure . The main emission peaks of these compounds are observed at 411 nm (λex = 260 nm) for 1, 415 nm (λex = 260 nm) for 2, 425 nm (λex = 300 nm) for 4, and 410 nm (λex = 300 nm) for 5. We have analyzed the photoluminescence properties of the free 3-PyHBIm and 4-PyHBIm ligands which show a narrow peak at ca. 390 nm in the solid state at room temperature. Compared to the free 3-PyHBIm and 4-PyHBIm ligands, the emission bands of 1, 2, 4, and 5 are 21, 25, 35, and 20 nm red-shifted, respectively. It has been reported that organic compound oba does not emit any luminescence in the range of 400–800 nm. The luminescence of the above compounds might be assigned to ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). In addition, it is noticeable that the emission of compound 4 is quite different from other compounds, which may be due to the different coordinate modes and combinations of 4-PyHBIm ligand in the structure. The result suggests that the structures and coordinate modes of ligands may have a significant influence on the luminescent property.

Photoluminescence Property

Coordination polymers with d10 metal centers have various fluorescence properties with potential applications in many fields such as chemical sensors, photochemistry, and light-emitting diodes (LEDs). The solid-state photoluminescent spectra of compounds 1, 2, 4, and 5 were measured at room temperature, and the results are given in Figure . The main emission peaks of these compounds are observed at 411 nm (λex = 260 nm) for 1, 415 nm (λex = 260 nm) for 2, 425 nm (λex = 300 nm) for 4, and 410 nm (λex = 300 nm) for 5. We have analyzed the photoluminescence properties of the free 3-PyHBIm and 4-PyHBIm ligands which show a narrow peak at ca. 390 nm in the solid state at room temperature. Compared to the free 3-PyHBIm and 4-PyHBIm ligands, the emission bands of 1, 2, 4, and 5 are 21, 25, 35, and 20 nm red-shifted, respectively. It has been reported that organic compound oba does not emit any luminescence in the range of 400-800 nm. The luminescence of the above compounds might be assigned to ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). In addition, it is noticeable that the emission of compound 4 is quite different from other compounds, which may be due to the different coordinate modes and combinations of 4-PyHBIm ligand in the structure. The result suggests that the structures and coordinate modes of ligands may have a significant influence on the luminescent property.

elements.content: A series of coordination polymers of different divalent metal ions with n-PyHBIm (n = 3, 4) and oba ligand have been successfully synthesized by hydrothermal reaction. The structures of these compounds, except for the isomorphous 1 and 2, are distinct from one another. The results imply that the metal centers have a significant influence on the structure of the compounds owing to their different coordination geometric requirements. And the position of nitrogen atom in n-PyHBIm ligands plays a pivotal role in forming coordination polymers. Moreover, the n-PyHBIm ligands can adopt different combinations to meet the coordination requirements of metal centers. The results of the present study suggest that the combination of n-PyHBIm and carboxylate ligands with suitable metal centers might form coordination polymers with interesting structures and topologies.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

A series of coordination polymers of different divalent metal ions with n-PyHBIm (n = 3, 4) and oba ligand have been successfully synthesized by hydrothermal reaction. The structures of these compounds, except for the isomorphous 1 and 2, are distinct from one another. The results imply that the metal centers have a significant influence on the structure of the compounds owing to their different coordination geometric requirements. And the position of nitrogen atom in n-PyHBIm ligands plays a pivotal role in forming coordination polymers. Moreover, the n-PyHBIm ligands can adopt different combinations to meet the coordination requirements of metal centers. The results of the present study suggest that the combination of n-PyHBIm and carboxylate ligands with suitable metal centers might form coordination polymers with interesting structures and topologies.

A solution of Zn(OAc)2·2H2O (23.0 mg, 0.105 mmol), 3-PyHBIm (19.6 mg, 0.1 mmol), oba acid (25.8 mg, 0.1 mmol), NaOH (4.0 mg, 0.1 mmol), and H2O (15 mL) was stirred under ambient conditions, then sealed in a Teflon-lined steel autoclave, heated at 160 °C for 5 days, and cooled to room temperature. Thermal stabilities of compounds 1–6. Themogravimetric analyses (TGA) for compounds 1–6 were performed in N2 atmosphere between 20 and 800 °C (). For compound 1, a weight loss of 6.9% was observed below 130 °C, which is attributed to the release of the coordinated and free water molecules (calcd. 6.5%), and then the decomposition of the framework occurred at about 350 °C. In the case of 2, there was a weight loss of 6.1% below 150 °C, which is attributed to the release of coordinated and free water molecules (calcd. 6.0%), and then the decomposition of the framework occurred at about 350 °C. Compound 3 showed a weight of 9.3% occurring in the range of 20–140 °C corresponding to the release of the coordinated and free water molecules (calcd. 9.3%), and then the framework started to decompose at about 200 °C. Compound 4 was stable up to near 390 °C and then began to decompose. For compound 5, there is a weight loss of 2.7% below 110 °C, which corresponds to the release of free water molecules (calcd. 2.3%), and then the decomposition of the framework occurred at about 380 °C. In the case of 6, there is a weight loss of 2.6% in the range of 20–150 °C corresponding to the release of the free water molecules (calcd. 2.5%), and then the decomposition of the framework occurred at about 300 °C.

Photoluminescence Property

Coordination polymers with d10 metal centers have various fluorescence properties with potential applications in many fields such as chemical sensors, photochemistry, and light-emitting diodes (LEDs). The solid-state photoluminescent spectra of compounds 1, 2, 4, and 5 were measured at room temperature, and the results are given in Figure . The main emission peaks of these compounds are observed at 411 nm (λex = 260 nm) for 1, 415 nm (λex = 260 nm) for 2, 425 nm (λex = 300 nm) for 4, and 410 nm (λex = 300 nm) for 5. We have analyzed the photoluminescence properties of the free 3-PyHBIm and 4-PyHBIm ligands which show a narrow peak at ca. 390 nm in the solid state at room temperature. Compared to the free 3-PyHBIm and 4-PyHBIm ligands, the emission bands of 1, 2, 4, and 5 are 21, 25, 35, and 20 nm red-shifted, respectively. It has been reported that organic compound oba does not emit any luminescence in the range of 400–800 nm. The luminescence of the above compounds might be assigned to ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). In addition, it is noticeable that the emission of compound 4 is quite different from other compounds, which may be due to the different coordinate modes and combinations of 4-PyHBIm ligand in the structure. The result suggests that the structures and coordinate modes of ligands may have a significant influence on the luminescent property.
